trial_identification.studytitle: Arginine and wound healing in patients recovering from a lower limb amputation
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effectiveness of an Arginine-enriched diet in patients with a lower-limb amputation. Does it reduce healing time and faciliate earlier prosthetic fitting?

interventions.interventions: Standard hospital diet plus two tetrapaks of a commercially available Arginie-enriched oral nutrition supplement (9g Arginine/day). The intervention will commence on entry to the study and will cease on the day that prosthetic casting occurs.
interventions.comparator: Standard hospital diet plus two tetrapaks of a commercially available oral nutrition supplement which is matched in terms of nutritional composition to the intervention except for the Arginine

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Day 0 (surgery) to day it is determined that wound is healed

primaryOutcome.outcome: Time to prosthetic casting and fitting
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Day 0 (surgery) to day of casting and fitting

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life measured by the AQoL
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline (entrance to the study) and discharge

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in nutritional health as determined by change in weight, Body Mass Index (BMI), corrected arm muscle area (CAMA) and nutritional intake
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at 3 day intervals until discharge from hospital

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All patients admitted to the Vascular unit at the Repatriation General Hospital for a trans-tibial or trans-femoral amputation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients who have not had a rigid removable dressing fitted within 24 hours of surgery. Patients receiving palliative care and ICU patients. Patients who are nil by mouth or who require enteral feeding or parenteral nutrition. Patients who are unable to fulfill the requirements of the study due to impaired cognition

trial_design.concealment: Research personnel will provide each potential participant with a patient information sheet outlining the study requirements. Patients willing to participate will sign an informed consent document, have all baseline measures performed and then be randomised. Treatment allocation will be sealed in foil lined envelopes by a person external ot the study. The allocation of participants to the trial will be maintained by the Pharmacy dept at the Repatriation General Hospital.
trial_design.sequence: A computerised number generator will be used to generate the randomisation sequence.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Patients admitted to RGH for a lower-limb amputation will be invited to participate in a study investigating the effect of a diet that is enriched with arginine on the time taken for the amputation wound to heal, and the time taken to have a prosthetic limb fitted. Participants will be allocated at random to receive either a standard hospital diet with 2 Arginine-enriched supplements or a standard hospital diet with 2 standard nutritional supplements, that are equal in energy, protein, vitamins and minerals. In addition to the time taken for the wound to heal, participants will also have their nutritional health measured via body weight, dietary intake and arm muscle stores. Quality of life will also be measured.
